references:
Specifically, to achieve secure random selectionÂ [50], Lotto allows each client in the population to
determine its participation in a training round by computing verifiable random functions (VRFs)Â [29, 51] using its secret key and public
inputs. Once a client decides to participate, Lotto collects the referred
randomness, along with the associated VRF proof, for other participants to
verify the generation of the randomness. This approach ensures that each
clientâ€™s participation is provably independent of, fair to, and unpredictable
for other clients. Yet, an adversarial server may still exploit this process
to grow the dishonest cohort, for example, by sending incorrect and/or a
selected subset of messages.
Lotto further mitigates such misconduct by enabling honest clients to verify critical messages.
Lotto provides a provable guarantee that the compromised fraction of selected participants remains minimum, thereby maintaining the security guarantees offered by secure aggregation and distributed DP (sectionÂ 3.4).

Fortunately, while enforcing execution integrity could be complex, the serverâ€™s ability to grow the ratio of dishonest participants can still be controlled indirectly by reasonable use of parameters in Lotto.
To ensure that dishonest clients remain a minority among the participants, regardless of how the server removes honest candidates, it is sufficient to guarantee that the number of dishonest candidates xâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²x^{\prime} is significantly smaller than the target number of participants sğ‘ s.
This way, even if the server deliberately includes all dishonest candidates in the final participants, as long as the number of participants is required to be fixed at sğ‘ s, the remaining participants, which constitute the majority, have to be honest clients.
To establish an upper bound for ğ”¼â€‹[xâ€²]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘¥â€²\mathbb{E}[x^{\prime}], we require a sufficiently large population size nğ‘›n, because ğ”¼â€‹[xâ€²]=câ‹…Î±â€‹s/nğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptğ‘¥â€²â‹…ğ‘ğ›¼ğ‘ ğ‘›\mathbb{E}[x^{\prime}]=c\cdot\alpha s/n and all parameters cannot be manipulated by the server except for nğ‘›n.
Thus, Lotto let honest clients agree upon a minimum acceptable population size, denoted as nminsubscriptğ‘›minn_{\text{min}}, and abort if the announced nğ‘›n falls below this threshold.

Lotto Induces Acceptable Overhead in Time.Â Â 
FigureÂ 8 summarizes the average round time in random selection, broken down into two parts: local training (â€˜trainâ€™), and the remaining workflow operations (â€˜otherâ€™).
It also shows the runtime portion of the latter, helping the reader understand the characteristics of various FL tasks.
When compared to Rand, Lotto implemented with Client-Centric incurs a time cost of less than 6%, 8%, and 10% for population sizes of 100, 400, and 700, respectively.
Moreover, the overhead for Server-Centric is 1%, 4%, and 3%, respectively.
Such acceptable overhead is expected as Lotto is built on lightweight security primitives (3.4).
As for informed selection, all the observed trends are identical to those reported in FigureÂ 8 (with Rand replaced by Oort).
We thus defer the results to AppendixÂ E for brevity.

FigureÂ 13 and FigureÂ 14 present a comparison between Lottoâ€™s informed selection and Oort in terms of average time cost and network footprint at the server end during a training round, respectively. When compared to Oort, the Lotto implementation using the Client-Centric approach incurs a time cost of less than 5%, 10%, and 5% for population sizes of 100, 400, and 700, respectively. Additionally, the overhead for Server-Centric is 2%, 0%, and 0%, respectively. Regarding the network footprint, Lotto introduces less than 1% additional network footprint across all evaluated tasks and participation scales. The observed trend indicates that Lotto maintains an acceptable time cost and negligible network overhead during informed selection, similar to the findings in random selection (sectionÂ 5.2).
